Package sprouts

Interface Var<T extends @Nullable Object>

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the wrapped item.
All Superinterfaces:
Maybe<T>, Val<T>
public interface Var<T extends @Nullable Object> extends Val<T>
A mutable wrapper for an item which can also be mapped to a weakly referencedViewable to be observed for changes using Actions registered through the Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) method, where the Channel is used to distinguish between changes from different sources (usually application layers like the view model or the view).
Use Val.view() to access a simple no-op live view of the item of this property and register change listeners on it to react to state changes.

The Channel constant passed to Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) ensures that the corresponding Action callback is only invoked when the Val.fireChange(Channel) method or the set(Channel, Object) method is invoked with the same Channel. Usually you will use the From constants to distinguish between important application layers using the From.VIEW_MODEL or From.VIEW channels.

Note that set(Object) method defaults to the From.VIEW_MODEL channel, which is intended to be used for state changes as part of your core business logic.

So for example if you have a Var which represents the username of a form, then inside your UI you can register a callback using Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) using the channel From.VIEW_MODEL which will update the UI accordingly when set(Object) is called inside you view model.
On the other hand, when the UI changes the property through the #set(From.View, object) method, all Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action) with the channel From.VIEW listeners will be notified.
Consider the following example property in your view model: 


      // A username property with a validation action:
      private final Var<String> username = Var.of("");
      private final Viewable<String> usernameView = this.username.view().onChange(From.VIEW v -> validateUser(v) );
And the following SwingTree example UI: 

      UI.textField("")
      .peek( tf -> vm.getUsernameView().onChange(From.VIEW_MODEL t -> tf.setText(t.get()) ) )
      .onKeyRelease( e -> vm.getUsername().set(From.VIEW, ta.getText() ) );
Here your view will automatically update the item of the text property and inside your view model you can freely update the username property, and it will then also automatically update the text field in the UI: 

      // Initially empty username:
      username.set( "" ) // triggers 'fireChange(From.VIEW_MODEL)'

If you no longer need to observe a property, you can use the Observable.unsubscribe(Subscriber) method to remove all Actions (which are also Subscribers) registered through Viewable.onChange(Channel, Action).

Note that the name of this class is short for "variable". This name was deliberately chosen because it is short, concise and yet clearly conveys the same meaning as other names used to model this kind of pattern, like "property", "observable object", "observable value", "observable property", etc. Using the names Var and Val also allows for the distinction between mutable and immutable properties without having to resort to prefixes like "mutable" or "immutable" as part of a type that is supposed to be used everywhere in your code.

Please take a look at the living sprouts documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

See Also:
  • A super type of this class with a read-only API.
  • A weakly referenced, read only live view of mutable properties to be used for registering change listeners.

  • Method Details

    • ofNullable

      static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNullable(Class<T> type, @Nullable T item)
      Use this factory method to create a new Var instance whose item may or may not be null.
      Var instances returned by this method will also report true for Val.allowsNull().

      Example: 

      
      Var.ofNullable(String.class, null);
      Note that it is required to supply a Class to ensure that the property can return a valid type when Maybe.type() is called.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property. This is not only used to check if the item is of the correct type, but also so that the property knows its type, even if the item is null.
      item - The initial item of the property, which may be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given type is null.

    • ofNull

      static <T> Var<@Nullable T> ofNull(Class<T> type)
      A more concise version of ofNullable(Class, Object) which is equivalent to Var.ofNullable(type, null).
      The Var instances returned by this factory method, are nullable, which means their Val.allowsNull() method will always yield true and they will not throw an IllegalArgumentException when set(Object) is called with a null item.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the wrapped item.
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance.

    • of

      static <T> Var<T> of(T item)
      This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object), but specifically designed to be used for MVVM.
      Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Var!
      Parameters:
      item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

    • of

      static <T, V extends T> Var<T> of(Class<T> type, V item)
      This factory method returns a Var describing the given non-null item similar to Optional.of(Object) and its type which may also be a super type of the supplied item.
      Var instances returned by this method will report false for Val.allowsNull(), because the item is guaranteed to be non-null.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the item held by the Var!
      V - The type of the item which is wrapped by the returned Var!
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item wrapped by the property, or a super type of it.
      item - The initial item of the property which must not be null.
      Returns:
      A new Var instance wrapping the given item.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the given item is null.

    • set

      default Var<T> set(T newItem)
      This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from the view model channel (see From.VIEW_MODEL). It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
      Parameters:
      newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
      Returns:
      This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the type of the supplied item does not match the Maybe.type() of this property in terms of being assignable:
      var.type().isAssignableFrom(newItem.getClass())

    • set

      Var<T> set(Channel channel, T newItem)
      This method provides the ability to modify the state of the wrapper from a custom channel of your choice, usually one of the channels defined in From. It might have several effects depending on the implementation.
      Parameters:
      channel - The channel from which the item is set.
      newItem - The new item which ought to replace the old one.
      Returns:
      This very wrapper instance, in order to enable method chaining.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If the type of the supplied item does not match the Maybe.type() of this property in terms of being assignable:
      var.type().isAssignableFrom(newItem.getClass())

    • update

      default Var<T> update(Function<T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible through this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.of(new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.update( it -> it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item (if it is not null) and applies the provided mapper function to it. The result will then be used to set the new item. So this is essentially a convenience method for the set(Object) method, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered when the item changes.

      Note that this method will not be called when the item is null, use updateNullable(Function) for that.
      Also note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      mapper - A function which take the current item and returns an item which will be used to set the new item. It is ignored in case of the property item being null.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • update

      default Var<T> update(Channel channel, Function<T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible through this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.of(new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.update(From.View, it -> it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item (if it is not null) and applies the given mapper function to it, which will then be used to set the new item on the supplied Channel. So this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Channel, Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that this method will not be called when the item is null, use updateNullable(Function) for that.
      Also note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      channel - The Channel for which the associated change listener should be invoked.
      mapper - A function which take the current item and returns an item which will be used to set the new item. It is ignored in case of the property item being null.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • updateNullable

      default Var<T> updateNullable(Function<@Nullable T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item, but this time the item can be null. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible using this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.ofNullable(Point.class, new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.updateNullable( it -> it == null ? it : it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item, even if it is null, and applies the given mapper function to it, whose result will then be used to set the new item. Note that this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      mapper - A function which take the current item or null and returns an item which will be used to set the new item.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • updateNullable

      default Var<T> updateNullable(Channel channel, Function<@Nullable T,@Nullable T> mapper)
      A common use-case is to update the item of a property based on the current item, but this time the item can be null. This is especially useful when your property holds larger value oriented types like records for which you want to update one of its fields through a wither.
      This is possible using this method, and it may look something like this: 
      
      record Point(int x, int y){...}
      var myProperty = Var.ofNullable(Point.class, new Point(1,2));
      myProperty.updateNullable(From.View, it -> it == null ? it : it.withY(42) );
      This takes the current item, even if it is null, and applies the given mapper function to it, which will then be used to set the new item on the supplied Channel. Note that this is essentially just a convenience method which will call the set(Channel, Object) for you, which means that the same change listeners will be triggered if the item changes.

      Note that any exceptions thrown by the mapper will not be caught and will be propagated to the caller.

      Parameters:
      channel - The Channel for which the associated change listener should be invoked.
      mapper - A function which take the current item or null and returns an item which will be used to set the new item.
      Returns:
      This property instance, to allow for fluent method chaining.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given mapper is null.

    • withId

      Var<T> withId(String id)
      Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.

      withId in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • map

      default Var<T> map(Function<T,T> mapper)
      If the item is present, then this applies the provided mapping function to it, and return it wrapped in a new Var instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.view(Function) method instead. This is essentially the same as Optional.map(Function) but based on Var as the wrapper instead of Optional.

      Specified by:
      map in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Specified by:
      map in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Parameters:
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to an item, if present.
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • mapTo

      default <U extends @Nullable Object> Var<@Nullable U> mapTo(Class<U> type, Function<@NonNull T,U> mapper)
      If the item is present, applies the provided mapping function to it, and returns it wrapped in a new Var instance.
      If the item is not present, then an empty Var instance is returned.

      But note that the resulting property does not constitute a live view of this property and will not be updated when this property changes.
      It is functionally very similar to the Optional.map(Function) method.

      If you want to map to a property which is an automatically updated live view of this property, then use the Val.viewAs(Class, Function) method instead.

      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Maybe<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Specified by:
      mapTo in interface Val<T extends @Nullable Object>
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      Parameters:
      type - The type of the item returned from the mapping function
      mapper - the mapping function to apply to an item, if present
      Returns:
      A new property either empty (containing null) or containing the result of applying the mapping function to the item of this property.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field on the property item type, using a getter and a wither function to access and update the field. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record Author with fields firstName, lastName, birthDate, and books. Using zoomTo, you can create lenses for each field to access and update them individually. 

      
   var author = new Author("John", "Doe", LocalDate.of(1829, 8, 12), Tuple.of("Book1", "Book2"));
   var authorProperty = Var.of(author);

   // Creating lenses for Author fields
   var firstNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::firstName, Author::withFirstName);
   var lastNameLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::lastName, Author::withLastName);
   var birthDateLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::birthDate, Author::withBirthDate);
   var booksLens = authorProperty.zoomTo(Author::books, Author::withBooks);

   // Usage example: Update the first name via the lens
   firstNameLens.set("Jane");

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of first value computed by the supplied getter, which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use zoomTo(Class, Function, BiFunction) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given getter or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Class<B> type, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the property item type, using explicit type information to ensure runtime type safety.

      This method solves a common issue where lenses created with zoomTo(Function, BiFunction) may encounter type cast exceptions when the focused field's runtime type differs from its declared supertype. By providing explicit type information through the type parameter, this method ensures the lens property correctly handles all subtypes of the declared type.

      For example, consider a record Person with a Number field: 

      
 record Person(String name, Number age) {
     public Person withAge(Number age) { return new Person(name, age); }
 }

 // Create a person with a Double age
 Var<Person> person = Var.of(new Person("Sam", 23.123d));
      Using a basic zoomTo may cause issues when setting a different subtype through the lens: 
      
 Var<Number> problematicAge = person.zoomTo(Person::age, Person::withAge);
 problematicAge.set(25); // Throws IllegalArgumentException at runtime! Integer =!= Double
      Using this method ensures type safety for lens updates: 
      
 Var<Number> safeAge = person.zoomTo(Number.class, Person::age, Person::withAge);
 safeAge.set(25); // Works correctly! Integer is accepted as Number

      The lens property returned by this method will accept any value that is assignable to the specified type, not just the specific runtime type of the initial value.

      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. This ensures runtime type safety and proper handling of subtypes.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, with proper type safety for all subtypes of B.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given type, getter, or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the current property item using a supplied Lens implementation. This method is used to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record TrainStation with various fields like name, location, and platforms. Using zoomTo, you can supply a Lens implementation to create a lens for a specific field. 

      
   record TrainStation(String name, String location, Tuple<Platform> platforms) {...}
   var lensToPlatforms = Lens.of(TrainStation::platforms, TrainStation::withPlatforms);
   // Create a TrainStation property
   var station = new TrainStation("Grand Central", "New York", Tuple.of(new Platform(1), new Platform(2)));
   var stationProperty = Var.of(station);
   // Create a stateful lens for the platforms field
   var platformsProperty = stationProperty.zoomTo(lensToPlatforms);
      Note that the Lens is a generic interface. So instead of the Lens.of(Function, BiFunction) factory method, you may also create more elaborate lenses through a custom implementation.
      The lens in the above example may also be created like so: 
      
   var lensToPlatforms = new Lens<TrainStation, Tuple<Platform>>() {
     public Tuple<Platform> getter( TrainStation station ) {
         return station.platforms();
     }
     public TrainStation wither( TrainStation station, Tuple<Platform> platforms ) {
         return station.withPlatforms(platforms);
     }
   };

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of first value computed by the supplied Lens.getter(Object), which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use zoomTo(Class, Lens) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given lens is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B> Var<B> zoomTo(Class<B> type, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the current property item using a supplied Lens implementation, with explicit type information for runtime safety.

      This method addresses the same type safety concerns as zoomTo(Class, Function, BiFunction) but works with pre-existing Lens instances. It ensures that the lens property correctly handles the full range of subtypes allowed by the declared type, not just the specific runtime type of the initial value.

      Example with a polymorphic measurement system: 

      
 sealed interface Measurement permits Length, Weight, Temperature {
     double value();
 }
 record Length(double meters) implements Measurement {}
 record Weight(double kilograms) implements Measurement {}

 record Product(String name, Measurement size) {
     public Product withSize(Measurement size) { return new Product(name, size); }
 }

 // Create a lens that can handle any Measurement subtype
 Lens<Product, Measurement> sizeLens = Lens.of(Product::size, Product::withSize);
 Var<Product> product = Var.of(new Product("Box", new Length(1.5)));

 // With explicit type information:
 Var<Measurement> size = product.zoomTo(Measurement.class, sizeLens);

 // Now we can safely change to different Measurement subtypes:
 size.set(new Weight(2.3)); // Works! Weight is a Measurement
 size.set(new Length(3.7)); // Also works! Length is a Measurement
      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared type of the field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. Provides runtime type information to handle all subtypes correctly.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, with proper handling of the declared type and all its subtypes.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given type or lens is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object> Var<B> zoomTo(B nullObject, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the item of this property, allowing a default value for whenever the item of this property is null. The lens property produced by this method will use the getter and wither functions to access and update a specific field in the item of this property. But in case of the item of this property being null, then the nullObject will be used as the non-null fallback value for the lens property produced by this method. This method is useful when you don't want your lens property to store null items, despite the parent object storing null items.

      For example, consider a record Book wrapped by a nullable Var<Book> property, which has a publisher field that we want to focus on and zoom into. Using zoomTo with a null object, you can create a lens for the publisher field even when the parent object is null. So when accessing the value of the lens, you will never have to worry about a NullPointerException. 

      
   // We declare a Book and a Publisher record
   record Book(String title, Publisher publisher) {...}
   record Publisher(String name) {...}

   // A nullable book property and a "null" publisher object
   var bookProperty = Var.ofNull(Book.class);
   Publisher nullPublisher = new Publisher("Unknown");

   // Creating a null safe lens property for the publisher field
   var publisherLens = bookProperty.zoomTo(nullPublisher,Book::publisher,Book::withPublisher);
   assert publisherLens.get() == nullPublisher;

   // Updating the book property with a new publisher
   var book = new Book("Some Title", new Publisher("Publisher1"));
   bookProperty.set(book);
   assert publisherLens.get() == book.publisher();

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of the supplied nullObject, which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use zoomTo(Class, Object, Function, BiFunction) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given getter or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object, V extends B> Var<B> zoomTo(Class<B> type, V nullObject, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific field of the item of this property, allowing a default value for whenever the item of this property is null, with explicit type safety.

      This method combines the null safety of zoomTo(Object, Function, BiFunction) with the type safety of zoomTo(Class, Function, BiFunction). It ensures the lens property correctly handles all subtypes of the declared type while providing a fallback for null parent items.

      Example with a polymorphic configuration system: 

      
 sealed interface Theme permits DarkTheme, LightTheme, HighContrastTheme {
     String primaryColor();
 }
 record DarkTheme() implements Theme {
     public String primaryColor() { return "#121212"; }
 }
 record LightTheme() implements Theme {
     public String primaryColor() { return "#FFFFFF"; }
 }

 record AppConfig(String name, Theme theme) {
     public AppConfig withTheme(Theme theme) { return new AppConfig(name, theme); }
 }

 // Nullable app config with default theme
 Var<AppConfig> config = Var.ofNull(AppConfig.class);
 Theme defaultTheme = new LightTheme();

 // Create a type-safe null-safe lens
 Var<Theme> themeLens = config.zoomTo(Theme.class, defaultTheme,
     AppConfig::theme, AppConfig::withTheme);

 // Initially uses default theme (parent is null)
 assert themeLens.get() == defaultTheme;

 // Can set any Theme subtype
 config.set(new AppConfig("MyApp", new DarkTheme()));
 themeLens.set(new HighContrastTheme()); // Works with any Theme implementation
      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      V - The specific subtype of B used for the null object.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. Ensures the lens accepts all subtypes, not just the null object's specific type.
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null, with full type safety for B.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the given type, null object, getter, or wither function is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object> Var<B> zoomTo(B nullObject, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) from the supplied Lens implementation, which focuses on a specific field of the potentially nullable item of this property, where a default non-null value is provided for cases when the item of this property is null. The lens property produced by this method will use the supplied Lens implementation to access and update a specific field in the item of this property. But in case of the item of this property being null, then the nullObject will be used as the non-null fallback value for the lens property produced by this method. This method is useful when you don't want your lens property to store null items, despite the parent object storing null items.

      For example, consider a record Book wrapped by a nullable Var<Book>, with a publisher field that we want to focus on. Using zoomTo with a null object, you can create a lens for the publisher field even when the parent object is null. So when accessing the value of the lens, you will never have to worry about a NullPointerException. 

      
   // We declare a Book and a Publisher record
   record Book(String title, Publisher publisher) {...}
   record Publisher(String name) {...}

   // A nullable book property and a "null" publisher object
   var bookProperty = Var.ofNull(Book.class);
   Publisher nullPublisher = new Publisher("Unknown");

   // Creating a null safe lens property for the publisher field
   var publisherLens = bookProperty.zoomTo(nullPublisher, Lens.of(Book::publisher,Book::withPublisher));
   assert publisherLens.get() == nullPublisher;

   // Updating the book property with a new publisher
   var book = new Book("Some Title", new Publisher("Publisher1"));
   bookProperty.set(book);
   assert publisherLens.get() == book.publisher();

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of the supplied nullObject, which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use zoomTo(Class, Object, Lens) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null. This object must not be null.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied nullObject or lens is null.

    • zoomTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object, V extends B> Var<B> zoomTo(Class<B> type, V nullObject, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a lens property (Var) from the supplied Lens implementation, which focuses on a specific field of the potentially nullable item of this property, with a default non-null value and explicit type safety.

      This method provides the combined benefits of null safety and type safety for pre-existing Lens instances. It ensures that the lens property can handle any subtype of the declared type while providing deterministic behavior for null parent items.

      Example with a polymorphic notification system: 

      
 sealed interface Notification permits EmailNotification, SmsNotification, PushNotification {
     String content();
 }

 record User(String name, Notification preference) {
     public User withPreference(Notification preference) {
         return new User(name, preference);
     }
 }

 // Nullable user with default notification preference
 Var<User> user = Var.ofNull(User.class);
 Notification defaultPref = new EmailNotification("default@example.com");
 Lens<User, Notification> prefLens = Lens.of(User::preference, User::withPreference);

 // Type-safe null-safe lens
 Var<Notification> preference = user.zoomTo(Notification.class, defaultPref, prefLens);

 // Works with any Notification subtype
 user.set(new User("Alice", new SmsNotification("+1234567890")));
 preference.set(new PushNotification("app://alert")); // Any Notification works
      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared type of the field that the lens will focus on, which must not be null.
      V - The specific subtype of B used for the null object.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. Provides runtime type information to handle all subtypes correctly.
      nullObject - The object to use when the focused field or its parent object is null. This object must not be null.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified field of the parent object, using the null object when the parent object is null, with proper type safety.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the supplied type, nullObject, or lens is null.

    • zoomToNullable

      default <B extends @Nullable Object> Var<B> zoomToNullable(Class<B> type, Function<T,B> getter, BiFunction<T,B,T> wither)
      Creates a nullable lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific nullable field of the current property item. The lens is used by the returned property to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific nullable field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record User with a nullable email field. Using zoomToNullable, you can create a lens specifically for the email field, which is a nullable String. 

      
 var user = new User("sam42", MembershipLevel.GOLD, LocalDate.of(2020, 1, 1), "sam.sus@example.com");
 var userProperty = Var.of(user);

 // Creating a lens for the nullable email field
 var emailLens = userProperty.zoomToNullable(String.class, User::email, User::withEmail);

 // Usage example: Update the email via the lens
 emailLens.set(null);
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the nullable field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class type of the nullable field.
      getter - Function to get the current value of the focused nullable field from the parent object.
      wither - BiFunction to set or update the value of the focused nullable field and return a new instance of the parent object with the updated field.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the type, getter, or wither function is null.

    • zoomToNullable

      default <B extends @Nullable Object> Var<B> zoomToNullable(Class<B> type, Lens<T,B> lens)
      Creates a nullable lens property (Var) that focuses on a specific nullable field of the current property item, using a supplied Lens implementation. The lens is used by the returned property to zoom into an immutable nested data structure, allowing read and write operations on a specific nullable field via getter and wither functions.

      For example, consider a record record Employee(String name, @Nullable Department department). Using zoomToNullable, you can supply a Lens implementation to create a lens for the department field, which is nullable. The lens will allow you to read and update the department field of the employee record, even if it is null. 

      
   record Employee(String name, @Nullable Department department) {...}
   record Department(String name) {...}

   var lensToDepartment = Lens.of(Employee::department, Employee::withDepartment);
   // Create an Employee property
   var employee = new Employee("Alice", null);
   var employeeProperty = Var.of(employee);
   // Create a nullable lens property for the department field
   var departmentProperty = employeeProperty.zoomToNullable(Department.class, lensToDepartment);
      Note that the Lens is a generic interface. So instead of the Lens.of(Function, BiFunction) factory method, you may also create more elaborate lenses through a custom implementation.
      The lens in the above example may also be created like so: 
      
   var lensToDepartment = new Lens<Employee, Department>() {
     public Department getter( Employee employee ) {
         return employee.department();
     }
     public Employee wither( Employee employee, Department department ) {
         return employee.withDepartment(department);
     }
   };
      Type Parameters:
      B - The type of the nullable field that the lens will focus on.
      Parameters:
      type - The class type of the nullable field.
      lens - The Lens implementation to focus on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Returns:
      A new Var that acts as a lens focusing on the specified nullable field of the parent object.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the type or lens is null.

    • projectTo

      default <B> Var<B> projectTo(Function<T,B> getter, Function<B,T> setter)
      Creates a projected lens property (Var) that bi-directionally maps between the item type T of this property and a target type B using a pair of conversion functions. The projection establishes a two-way relationship where changes in either property are automatically reflected in the other, provided the conversion functions form an isomorphism (a perfect reversible mapping).

      This method is particularly useful when you need to work with different representations of the same logical data. For example, converting between measurement units, currency values, or different string encodings while maintaining synchronization between the representations.

      Mathematical Foundation:
      For the projection to behave predictably, the functions should ideally form an isomorphism: getter and setter must be inverse functions of each other. Formally, for all t of type T: setter.apply(getter.apply(t)).equals(t) should hold true, and for all b of type B: getter.apply(setter.apply(b)).equals(b) should hold true.

      Important Considerations:

      • Non-isomorphic functions may cause unexpected behavior: If the functions are not perfect inverses, updates may not round-trip correctly, leading to data corruption or infinite update loops.
      • Injectivity is required for writes: The setter function should be injective (one-to-one) to ensure that different B values map to distinct T values, preventing ambiguous updates.
      • Surjectivity is required for coverage: The getter should be surjective (onto) to ensure all possible B values can be represented in the T domain.

      Example - Unit Conversion: 

      
 sealed interface Quant {
   record MilliMeter(double val) implements Quant {}
   record Meter(double val) implements Quant {}
   record KiloMeter(double val) implements Quant {}

   default MilliMeter toMM() {
     return switch (this) {
       case MilliMeter mm -> mm;
       case Meter m -> new MilliMeter(m.val * 1_000d);
       case KiloMeter km -> new MilliMeter(km.val * 1_000_000d);
     };
   }

   default Meter toM() {
     return switch (this) {
       case MilliMeter mm -> new Meter(mm.val / 1_000d);
       case Meter m -> m;
       case KiloMeter km -> new Meter(km.val * 1_000d);
     };
   }

   default KiloMeter toKM() {
     return switch (this) {
       case MilliMeter mm -> new KiloMeter(mm.val / 1_000_000d);
       case Meter m -> new KiloMeter(m.val / 1_000d);
       case KiloMeter km -> km;
     };
   }
 }

 void example() {
   var mmRaw = new Quant.MilliMeter(6_200d);
   Var<Quant.MilliMeter> mm = Var.of(mmRaw);
   Var<Quant.Meter> m = mm.projectTo(Quant::toM, Quant::toMM);
   Var<Quant.KiloMeter> km = m.projectTo(Quant::toKM, Quant::toM);

   // Initial state:
   // mm.get().val() == 6_200d
   // m.get().val() == 6.2d
   // km.get().val() == 0.0062d

   m.set(new Quant.Meter(13.4));

   // After update:
   // mm.get().val() == 13_400d
   // m.get().val() == 13.4d
   // km.get().val() == 0.0134d
 }
      In this example, the conversion functions between metric units form a perfect isomorphism (linear scaling), ensuring that updates propagate correctly in both directions without loss of precision.

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of first value computed by the supplied getter, which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use projectTo(Class, Function, Function) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The target type of the projected property.
      Parameters:
      getter - Function that converts from T to B. Must be surjective to cover all possible B values.
      setter - Function that converts from B back to T. Must be injective to ensure unambiguous updates.
      Returns:
      A new Var that maintains a bidirectional projection to/from this property's item type.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either function is null.
      See Also:
      • for a version with null safety.
      • for nullable projections.

    • projectTo

      default <B> Var<B> projectTo(Class<B> type, Function<T,B> getter, Function<B,T> setter)
      Creates a projected lens property (Var) that bi-directionally maps between the item type T of this property and a target type B using conversion functions, with explicit type safety.

      This method addresses the same type safety issue as the lens methods, but for projections. When using projectTo(Function, Function), the runtime type of the projected property is inferred from the initial converted value, which may be a subtype of the declared type B. This method ensures the projection accepts all valid subtypes of B.

      Example with a polymorphic serialization system: 

      
 sealed interface DataFormat permits JsonFormat, XmlFormat, YamlFormat {
     String serialize(Object data);
     Object deserialize(String text);
 }

 record Document(String title, Object content) {
     public Document withContent(Object content) { return new Document(title, content); }
 }

 // Project Document content to various DataFormat representations
 Var<Document> doc = Var.of(new Document("Report", Map.of("key", "value")));

 // Without explicit type: limited to the initial format's specific type
 // Var<DataFormat> problematic = doc.projectTo(d -> new JsonFormat(d.content()), ...);

 // With explicit type safety: accepts any DataFormat implementation
 Var<DataFormat> format = doc.projectTo(DataFormat.class,
     d -> new JsonFormat(d.content()),  // Convert to JsonFormat (a DataFormat)
     f -> new Document("Report", f.deserialize(f.serialize()))
 );

 // Can switch between different DataFormat implementations
 format.set(new XmlFormat(doc.get().content())); // Works! XmlFormat is a DataFormat
 format.set(new YamlFormat(doc.get().content())); // Also works!
      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared target type of the projected property.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. Ensures the projection accepts all subtypes, not just the initial converted type.
      getter - Function that converts from T to B.
      setter - Function that converts from B back to T.
      Returns:
      A new Var that maintains a bidirectional projection to/from this property's item type, with proper handling of all B subtypes.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if type, getter, or setter is null.

    • projectTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object> Var<B> projectTo(B nullObject, Function<T,B> getter, Function<B,T> setter)
      Creates a projected lens property (Var) that bi-directionally maps between the item type T of this property and a target type B using conversion functions, with a guaranteed non-null fallback value for when this property's item is null.

      This method is similar to projectTo(Function, Function) but provides null safety by ensuring the projected property never contains null. When this property's item is null, the projected property will use the provided nullObject as its value.

      Mathematical Foundation:
      The functions should form a partial isomorphism on the non-null subset of T.

      • For non-null t: setter.apply(getter.apply(t)).equals(t) should hold,
      • and for all b: getter.apply(setter.apply(b)).equals(b) should hold.
      The nullObject serves as the image of null under the mapping.

      Important Considerations:

      • Non-isomorphic functions may cause data loss: As with projectTo, imperfectly reversible functions can lead to inconsistent states.
      • Null handling is explicit: The nullObject is used whenever this property contains null, providing a deterministic fallback.
      • The nullObject should be semantically meaningful: Choose a value that makes sense as a default representation of "empty" or "uninitialized" state.

      Example - Encryption with Null Safety: 
      
    var key = createEncryptionKey();
    Var<String> plain = Var.ofNullable(String.class, "message");
    Var<String> secret = plain.projectTo("", key::encrypt, key::decrypt);

    // Initial: plain.get() = "message", secret.get() = "encrypted_message"

    plain.set(null);
    // Now: plain.get() = null, secret.get() = "" (the nullObject)

    secret.set("different_encrypted");
    // Now: plain.get() = "different_decrypted", secret.get() = "different_encrypted"
      In this example, empty string serves as the encrypted representation of null. The encryption/decryption functions should be isomorphic for non-null strings to ensure perfect round-trip conversion.

      Warning:
      The Maybe.type() of the property returned by this method will be resolved dynamically from the Object.getClass() of the supplied nullObject, which is always a concrete (sub)type.
      This means that if the type system treats B as a super type of many possible subtypes, then you may encounter a mismatch between the implied type Var<B> and the Class<B> returned by Maybe.type(), which leads to type cast exceptions in the property.
      Use projectTo(Class, Object, Function, Function) to avoid this particular issue!

      Type Parameters:
      B - The target type of the projected property (non-nullable).
      Parameters:
      nullObject - The fallback value to use when this property's item is null. This object must not be null.
      getter - Function that converts from T to B for non-null items.
      setter - Function that converts from B back to T.
      Returns:
      A new Var that maintains a bidirectional projection with guaranteed non-null values, using nullObject as fallback.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if nullObject or either function is null.

    • projectTo

      default <B extends @NonNull Object, V extends B> Var<B> projectTo(Class<B> type, V nullObject, Function<T,B> getter, Function<B,T> setter)
      Creates a projected lens property (Var) that bi-directionally maps between the item type T of this property and a target type B using conversion functions, with a guaranteed non-null fallback value and explicit type safety.

      This method combines null safety with type safety for projections. It ensures the projected property never contains null while accepting any subtype of the declared type B.

      Example with a polymorphic UI component system: 

      
 sealed interface Widget permits Button, TextField, Slider {
     String render();
 }

 record UiState(Widget currentWidget) {
     public UiState withWidget(Widget widget) { return new UiState(widget); }
 }

 // Nullable UI state with default widget
 Var<UiState> ui = Var.ofNull(UiState.class);
 Widget defaultWidget = new Button("Click me");

 // Type-safe null-safe projection
 Var<Widget> widget = ui.projectTo(Widget.class, defaultWidget,
     UiState::currentWidget,
     UiState::withWidget
 );

 // Initially shows default widget (parent is null)
 assert widget.get() == defaultWidget;

 // Can set any Widget implementation
 ui.set(new UiState(new TextField("Enter text")));
 widget.set(new Slider(0, 100, 50)); // Works with any Widget
      Type Parameters:
      B - The declared target type of the projected property (non-nullable).
      V - The specific subtype of B used for the null object.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing the declared type B. Ensures the projection accepts all subtypes, not just the null object's type.
      nullObject - The fallback value to use when this property's item is null. This object must not be null.
      getter - Function that converts from T to B for non-null items.
      setter - Function that converts from B back to T.
      Returns:
      A new Var that maintains a bidirectional projection with guaranteed non-null values, using nullObject as fallback, with full type safety for B.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if type, nullObject, getter, or setter is null.

    • projectToNullable

      default <B extends @Nullable Object> Var<B> projectToNullable(Class<B> type, Function<T,B> getter, Function<B,T> setter)
      Creates a projected lens property (Var) that bi-directionally maps between the item type T of this property and a nullable target item type B using conversion functions. This method allows the projected property to hold null values, which is useful when the conversion between types is partial or may fail.

      Mathematical Foundation:
      The functions define a partial bijection between subsets of T and B.
      For the subset where conversion is defined:

      • setter.apply(getter.apply(t)).equals(t) should hold
      • getter.apply(setter.apply(b)).equals(b) should hold
      Outside this subset, null serves as an explicit representation of "no valid conversion".

      Important Considerations:

      • Partial functions require careful handling: When getter returns null (indicating no valid conversion), setter should handle null appropriately, typically by returning a sensible default or sentinel value.
      • Non-isomorphic behavior is expected: Unlike projectTo, this method explicitly accommodates non-isomorphic conversions by allowing null as a valid state.
      • Null propagation: If this property's item is null, the projected property will also be null, unless getter handles null explicitly.

      Example - String to Double Parsing with Error Handling: 

      
    Var<String> text = Var.of("1ooo"); // Note: contains 'o' instead of '0'
    Var<Double> num = text.projectToNullable(
        Double.class,
        s -> {
            try {
                return Double.parseDouble(s);
            } catch (Exception e) {
                return null; // Conversion failed
            }
        },
        d -> d == null ? "" : d.toString()
    );

    // Initial: text.get() = "1ooo", num.get() = null (parsing failed)

    text.set("3.14");
    // Now: text.get() = "3.14", num.get() = 3.14

    num.set(null);
    // Now: text.get() = "", num.get() = null
      This example demonstrates graceful handling of conversion failures through null. The projection maintains synchronization for valid conversions while using null to represent unconvertible states.
      Type Parameters:
      B - The nullable target type of the projected property.
      Parameters:
      type - The class object representing type B, required for runtime type information and nullability support.
      getter - Function that converts from T to B, returning null when conversion is not possible or meaningful.
      setter - Function that converts from B back to T, handling null input appropriately.
      Returns:
      A new Var that maintains a bidirectional projection allowing null values in both directions.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if type or either function is null.
